Ballesteros-Plata A. Infantes-Molina ⁎ M. Rodríguez-Cuadrado E. Rodríguez-Aguado P. Braos-García E. Rodríguez-Castellón Departamento de Química Inorgánica, Cristalografía y Mineralogía (Unidad Asociada al ICP-CSIC), Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de Málaga, Campus de Teatinos, 29071 Málaga, Spain Departamento de Química Inorgánica Cristalografía y Mineralogía (Unidad Asociada al ICP-CSIC) Facultad de Ciencias Universidad de Málaga Campus de Teatinos Málaga 29071 Spain ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Molybdenum was incorporated into catalysts based on noble metals (Pt or Pd) and supported on silica in order to evaluate how its presence can modify the catalytic response of monometallic catalysts for hydrodeoxygenation (HDO). To this end, the catalysts were evaluated in the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) reaction of dibenzofuran (DBF) and characterized by different experimental techniques to understand its structure, texture and acidic properties. Catalytic results showed that the active phase had much influence on the activity and selectivity to different reaction products, although, in all cases, bicyclohexane (BCH) was the main reaction product observed. Molybdenum played a very important role in the case of bimetallic catalysts, mainly in the case of palladium. Molybdenum species improved the selectivity to O-free products related to its capacity to break the CO bond. However, molybdenum activity was nil in the absence of noble metal. Moreover, regardless of the noble metal employed, the reducibility, acidity and dispersion of the molybdenum species changed and this is possibly associated to a synergism effect between noble metal and Mo. Keywords HDO Dibenzofuran (DBF) Noble metals Molybdenum SiO2 Pt Pd 1 Introduction The use of bioenergy as a renewable alternative to fossil fuels is nowadays attracting more and more attention. The reasons for this are obvious: our world is running out of oil reserves, the raw oil quality is decreasing, and energy security is a hot topic on our political agenda just like global climate change [1]. Biofuels seem to be a potential energy complement for fossil fuels since it is a renewable resource that could contribute to sustainable development and global environmental preservation. It has positive environmental properties such as reduced greenhouse gas emissions and it appears to have significant economic potential [2]. Bio-oil obtained from fast pyrolysis of biomass contains a complex mixture of oxygenated compounds with more than 300 different compounds having been identified [3]; it has an approximate composition of total-water (20–30% by weight), lignin fragments (15–30wt%), aldehydes (10–20wt%), carboxylic acid (10–15wt%), carbohydrates (5–10wt%), phenols (2–5wt%), furfural (1–4wt%), alcohols (2–5wt%), and ketones (1–5wt%). The oxygen content in bio-oils obtained from fast pyrolysis varies in the range of 35–60wt% on a wet basis which confers undesirable properties [3,4]. Therefore, if pyrolysis-oil wants to be a competitive substitute for petroleum fuels, an upgrade is required [5]. The hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) process is suitable for this, where oxygen is removed in the presence of hydrogen and a suitable catalyst [6]. Noble metal supported catalysts have shown good results in HDO reactions [7], being active even at low temperatures. This gives the catalytic system a series of advantages such as the possibility of avoiding thermal reactions that lead to gum and operational instability; this thus prevents coke formation and deactivation. One important requirement in HDO is the necessity of bi-functional catalysts, that is, with active centers able to activate hydrogen as well as acidic sites to interact with O-containing molecules [8]. In this sense, research attention has been directed towards catalysts based on noble metals in response to deactivation and degradation of catalysts based on transition metal sulfides for HDO processes. Supported noble metals are attractive due to their capability to activate H2 while they do not require a continuous sulfur feed and are less susceptible to deactivation by water; therefore, longer lifetimes of the catalysts are expected [7]. Recent studies showed good activity for Ru-, Pd- and Pt-supported catalysts compared to traditional catalysts for hydrotreating bio-oil [9], and particularly, in the HDO of dibenzofuran (DBF) [10]. Pd and Pt supported on mesoporous ZSM-5 zeolites have also been studied in the hydrogenation of phenol [11,12], where all of them showed interesting results in terms of HDO activity. On the other hand, there are many studies on Mo-based catalysts, Mo2C, MoS2, MoO3, Ni-Mo-S, and Co-Mo-S, where their high-selective deoxygenation activity is reported [13]. The Mo2C catalyst is highly selective to deoxygenation without hydrogenation of furanic or aromatic rings, leading to a direct scission of CO or CO bond of the intermediate [14,15]. In line with this, a recent research on catalysts based on carbide, nitride, phosphide, and molybdenum oxide supported on titanium oxide in the HDO reaction of phenol, has revealed that the catalyst Mo2C/TiO2 was the most active, presenting high selectivity towards benzene [16]. However, molybdenum carbide catalyst can be deactivated in the presence of water, oxidizing Mo2C to MoO2 [17]. The MoS2, Ni-Mo-S, and Co-Mo-S catalysts are known due to the role of the MoS2 active phase and sulfur vacancy sites (CUS) in the direct scission of the CO bond through the direct deoxygenation pathway. Likozar et al. [18–20] studied the hydrotreatment of solvolytic primary oil, obtained with low-temperature liquefaction of lignocellulosic biomass waste by using different solvents and Mo-based catalysts. The results obtained showed that the sulfide-form of the commercial NiMo/ɣAl2O3 catalyst gave rise to a more suitable liquid product with an oxygen content less than 1.7wt%, while the high-gross calorific value of the liquid phase was obtained by the oxide form of the NiMo catalyst; on the other hand, the bulk MoS2 catalyst is promising due to its low cost and relatively high catalytic activity and selectivity toward deoxygenated products. However, sulfided Mo-based catalysts require continuous replenishment of sulfur through external sulfiding agents such as H2S or CS2 to maintain the catalytic activity due to the absence of sulfur in bio-oils [21]. Molybdenum oxide catalysts have also been studied in the deoxygenation of model compounds. They promote hydrogenolysis and direct scission of a CO bond [16,22]. The deoxygenation mechanism involves interaction of oxygenated compound with oxygen vacant sites to form a Mo-O bond and the direct cleavage of the CO bond from the adsorbed intermediate. Thus, it is considered that the concentration of oxygen vacant sites has a significant effect on the catalytic performance of molybdenum oxide. Thus, Román Leshkov et al. [23] highlighted the high activity of MoO3 in HDO at mild operation conditions and presenting high selectivity to direct deoxygenation products without prior aromatic ring saturation. In line with this, Shetty et al. [24] have evaluated the activity of MoO3 supported on SiO2, α-Al2O3, TiO2, and CeO2 in the vapor-phase hydrodeoxygenation of m-cresol. These authors concluded that the most active catalysts were those presenting a greater proportion of Mo5+ and Mo3+ species in the MoO3 oxide supported on TiO2 and ZrO2. In contrast, a high proportion of Mo6+ species seemed to be detrimental. In this work, the incorporation of molybdenum into noble metal catalysts has been evaluated, supported on a support presenting very low acidity in order to create the required bi-functionality. The CO cleavage activity of molybdenum previously reported, along with the hydrogenation capability of noble metals, could be a good conjunction to prepare highly active catalysts in HDO. Moreover, we have considered the evaluation of two different noble metals also presenting different hydrogenation capability. Thus, Pd and Pt were the metals chosen and DBF the model molecule studied at different experimental conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts The metals were supported on SiO2 (fumed silica from Sigma Aldrich) and were prepared by following the incipient wetness impregnation method. The appropriate amounts of Pt and Mo or Pd and Mo precursor salts were dissolved in the incipient volume of water, referred to gram of silica employed, to achieve the desired concentrations. (NH4)2PtCl4 99.9% and PdCl2 99.9%, from Aldrich, and (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, 99%, from Alfa Aesar, were used as the Pt, Pd, and Mo sources, respectively. In the case of the Pd containing solution, concentrated HCl acid was also added to dissolve PdCl2 (0.1mL HCl/mL solution). The obtained solutions were added to the support and, after drying at 60°C for 12h, the resulting solids were calcined at 450°C for 2h [25]. They will be, hereafter, referred to as “fresh catalysts”. These catalysts contain a total metal loading (Pt or Pd plus Mo) of 2wt%, the Pt(Pd)/Mo atomic ratio being equal to 1, and will be denoted as PtMo/Si and PdMo/Si. Thus, the PtMo/Si sample contains 1.3wt% Pt and 0.7wt% Mo and the PdMo/Si sample contains 1.1wt% Pd and 0.9wt% Mo. For comparison purposes, the corresponding monometallic phases, with metal loadings equal to 1wt%, were also prepared. These samples will be denoted as Pt/Si, Pd/Si, and Mo/Si. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts BET specific surface areas were obtained from nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms at −196°C on a Micrometric ASAP 2020 apparatus with all samples outgassed at 200°C for 10h prior to analysis. The total pore volumes were calculated from the adsorption branches of the isotherms at P/P0 =0.95. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns of fresh catalysts were collected on a PAN analytical X’Pert Pro automated diffractometer. Powder patterns were recorded between 10 and 80° in 2θ, with a step size of 0.0167° (2θ) and an equivalent counting time of ∼60s/step in Bragg-Brentano reflection configuration by using a Ge (111) primary monochromator (CuKα1) and the X’Celerator detector. The acidity of the pure support and as-prepared catalysts was determined by temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of ammonia measurements. To that end, 80mg of solid were put in a quartz sample holder through which a flow of He was passed while the temperature was risen from room temperature to 450°C; after having left it to cool to 100°C, an ammonia flow was passed for 5min. Once the physisorbed ammonia was removed at the same temperature by flushing with He (35mLmin−1), the TPD experiment was carried out rising the temperature up to 800°C at a constant heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 under the same He flow. The effluent composition was determined using a TCD detector. The reducibility of the samples was studied by temperature-programmed reduction in flowing H2 (H2-TPR); each sample was cleaned in a flow of He (35mLmin−1) at 100°C for half an hour; after cooling the furnace to 45°C, samples were then heated in a H2 flow (45mLmin−1) to 700°C using a heating ramp of 10°Cmin−1. The measurement was recorded on a Shimadzu GC-14b chromatograph. High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM) micrographs of fresh catalysts, supported on a Cu grid, were obtained by using a Philips CCCM 200 Supertwin−DX4 microscope. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were performed on a Physical Electronics PHI 5701 spectrometer, using non0monochromatic Al-Kα radiation (300W, 15kV, 1486.6eV) provided with a multi-channel detector. Samples were analyzed in a constant pass-energy mode at 29.35eV. Charge referencing was measured against Si 2p at 103.4eV. 2.3 Catalytic activity The prepared catalysts were evaluated in the HDO reaction employing DBF as the model molecule. The hydrotreating reaction was performed in a high-pressure fixed-bed continuous-flow stainless steel catalytic reactor with an interior placed thermocouple in direct contact with the catalytic bed. The liquid O-containing feed was supplied with a Gilson 307SC piston pump (model 10SC). For the activity tests, 0.25g of fresh catalyst (particle size 0.85–1.00mm) was used, diluted with SiC to 3cm3. The catalytic activity was measured on DBF at two different pressures (1.5 and 3.0MPa) at 275°C, and at two different temperatures (250 and 275°C) under 3.0MPa of H2. In all cases, the H2 flow rate was 30mLmin−1 and the organic feed flow 0.18 mLmin−1. The activity is described in terms of the HDO conversion according to Eq (1): (1) X H D O = n o h − Σ n o x i n o h × 100 where n0h is the initial amount of DBF and noxi are the amounts of oxygenated compounds. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization All samples, fresh and spent catalysts, were studied by XRD; the corresponding diffractograms are shown in Fig. 1 . In all cases, a broad band at 2θ between 20° and 30°, characteristic of amorphous materials, was found. Well-defined diffraction lines could be seen in the case of Pt-based catalysts, PtMo/Si, at 2θ=39.7°, 46.3°, and 67.3°, which are assigned to Pt0 phase (PDF 00-001-1190); no lines indicative of the presence of any Pt-oxide phase could be detected in any of the Pt catalysts (neither before nor after the catalytic test). In contrast, in the case of PdMo/Si catalysts, only palladium oxide (PdO) could be identified in the fresh catalyst, according to the signal centered at 2θ=33.8° (PDF 00-041-1107). Nevertheless, after the catalytic test, this signal is no more present while new ones appeared at 2θ=40.1° and 46.7° (PDF 03-065-6174), which are assigned to Pd0 (due to the reduction of PdO to Pd metal under the catalytic test conditions). The diffraction peak at 2θ=59.9° (PDF 01-074-2307) that can be seen in the Pd-spent catalyst (see Fig. 1A) corresponds to the SiC particles that were not efficiently separated from the used sample. Furthermore, no diffraction signals indicative of any Mo species were detected. From these diffractograms, it seems that Pd was better dispersed than Pt. By using Scherrer’s equation, the particle size was 8nm vs 20.6nm, respectively. If monometallic samples are considered (Fig. 1B), it is noteworthy that with only 1wt% loading, diffraction peaks of bulk MoO3 can be observed (PDF 00-005-0508) in the monometallic Mo-containing catalyst, suggesting that interaction with the support is weak and, consequently, all the molybdenum must be in the form of bulk MoO3. However, co-impregnation with the noble metal salts leads to better dispersed MoO3 species particles and/or less crystalline Mo species, which are not detectable by XRD. However, the opposite is found for the noble metals based catalysts; that is to say, no diffraction lines are detected for the monometallic Pd and Pt fresh catalysts, indicative of the high dispersion of the loaded species, in contrast to the corresponding bimetallic materials. Thus, it seems clear that both components of the active phase in the bimetallic catalysts exert an effect on the dispersion of each other. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the support and the fresh catalysts are represented in Fig. 2 ; the corresponding BET surface area values are listed in Table 1 . The bare support isotherm is of II type, according the IUPAC classification [26] characteristic of solids with pores of diameters mainly in the range of meso and macropores, and generally attributed to interparticle voids. In relation to those corresponding to supported catalysts, the main difference appreciated is the sharp increment in the volumes of N2 adsorbed for relative pressure values higher than 0.8, indicating the presence of pores of a higher diameter. As described for other catalysts [25], the active-phase particles must have deposited mainly in those interparticle voids of fume silica; this thus explains the increase in the absorbed volume at high relative pressures. Considering monometallic samples, their apparent surface area values did not differ considerably compared to the bimetallic ones. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was carried out in order to better understand the active phase dispersion of the prepared samples. The micrographs corresponding to PdMo/Si are presented in Fig. 3 , as well as the corresponding particle size distribution graph. The micrographs show the presence of small metallic particles highly dispersed on the material support, the majority of particle sizes being within the range 1.0–4.0nm, although particles with sizes up to 12–14nm can also be seen. The same can be said in the case of the PtMo/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. 4 ), yet a comparison of the particle size distribution of both the Pt- and Pd-based catalysts, indicates that the PtMo/Si shows a narrower particle size distribution. However, this catalyst presents some metallic particle agglomerates (red circles) that are almost absent in the case of the Pd catalyst (see Figs. 3A and 4A). These data are consistent with those previously described by XRD, where the catalyst PtMo/Si showed diffraction peaks much better defined than those respective to the Pd catalyst; this thus suggests a better dispersion of the metallic phase in the latter case. Moreover, the mapping analysis of the elements on the surface is represented in Fig. 5 . A homogeneous distribution of both metals on the catalyst is observed. Moreover, it is clearly observed zones where Mo and noble-metal particles are independent and other where both metals are in close contact. So, in general, material heterogeneity is observed. The total amounts of acid centers as well as their strength were determined by NH3-TPD of silica supported mono- and bimetallic catalysts, the corresponding values (μmol NH3 g−1) being included in Table 1, except for those relative to a pure SiO2 support as no significant NH3 desorption was detected in this case. The addition of MoO3 to the support greatly increases the amount of total ammonia desorbed, mainly in the range of weak-strength acidity. Nevertheless, this increment of acidity is moderate in the case of monometallic Pd or Pt catalysts. Regarding the bimetallic catalysts, they resemble the noble metal monometallic ones as they are very different from the Mo sample. These data points again indicate some interaction between the noble metal and the molybdenum species that controls the acidity of the resultant sample. All fresh samples, including the monometallic catalysts, were studied by temperature-programmed reduction in flowing H2; the corresponding reduction profiles are depicted in Fig. 6 . In the case of monometallic Mo supported catalyst, a broad band can be observed at temperatures higher than 300–400°C, with a maximum at 520°C, although when the TPR experiment is finished, the H2 consumption line rises again before achieving the base-line level. This result is in good agreement with those described in literature for molybdenum oxide supported on silica [27,28], with two broad bands, and quite different from that found for the reduction of the pure molybdenum oxide, MoO3, which requires higher temperatures to be reduced [29]. With regards to the origin of those signals, the one observed at lower temperature has been assigned to the reduction of bulk MoO3 to Mo(IV). In our case, the integration of the profile curve at temperatures lower than 650°C gives rise to a H2 consumption which is almost equal to the amount of Mo loaded in the reactor, leading to a H2/Mo molar ratio of 1.01. Thus, we assume that all Mo(VI) present in the sample is in the form of bulk MoO3, in good agreement with diffraction peaks found for this sample. Furthermore, this supported MoO3 can be reduced to Mo(IV) at temperatures lower than 650°C. This result suggests that total reduction of Mo is prevented in the temperature range studied, a phenomenon already described in the literature [28]. Regarding the noble metal containing catalysts, despite having employed double amount of sample, the obtained signals are so weak that reliable quantification is not possible. Thus, the supported monometallic Pt catalyst shows a weak and broad band centered at ca. 127°C, which barely accounts for the 6–8% of hydrogen required to reduce the Pt present in the sample (assumed to be Pt(II) oxide, as will be discussed later). This clearly indicates that almost all the Pt in the sample is already in the form of metallic, well dispersed particles, formed as a consequence of the decomposition of the precursor salt, (NH4)2PtCl4, which is described to produce metallic Pt on heating even in an O2 atmosphere [30]. Thus, this small hydrogen consumption is probably due to reduction of the Pt-oxide species formed on the surface of the metallic particles on exposure to air [31]. In contrast, for the monometallic Pd catalyst, only a negative signal at 93°C, assigned to the desorption of H2 from Pd0, can be observed, with no significant consumption signals at higher temperatures, which leads to the conclusion that all Pd is reduced to the metallic form prior to the TPR experiment. Nonetheless, in this case, it has to be kept in mind that while stabilizing the baseline, the sample is subjected to a H2 flow at 45°C, and, in such conditions, the PdO formed during calcination of the sample can be reduced and absorb H2 [32,33]. In the case of the bimetallic catalysts (PtMo/Si and PdMo/Si), the observed profiles are very similar to those observed for Pt/Si and Pd/Si, but with a slight increase in signal intensity. For the PtMo bimetallic catalyst, the band centered at 127°C has almost vanished, while the desorption band present in the Pd-containing catalyst has become more prominent. Upon XRD data, it seems that the co-impregnation method employed has led to partial agglomeration of the Pt0 and PdO particles, respectively. This could explain the lower consumption of H2 in the case of the platinum bimetallic catalyst if we assume that the signal is due to the reduction of platinum oxide formed on the surface of bigger Pt0 particles. Similarly, bigger Pd0 particles in the bimetallic sample would have a higher H2 absorption capacity. However, the more remarkable feature of the TPR profiles of the bimetallic catalysts is the absence of any H2 consumption signal at temperatures above 200–300°C that could be assigned to the reduction of any Mo species. These results contrast those described by other authors [34], who found that, for bimetallic supported catalysts, the presence of metallic particles lead to a decrease in the temperature of reduction of MoO3 to MoO2, the intensity of the corresponding signal being almost unaltered. This effect was attributed to the activation of hydrogen on the metallic particles and ulterior spillover on the support. Nevertheless, there were no changes in the high-temperature signal assigned to the reduction of Mo(VI). Given that the formation of an oxide or oxohydroxide of Mo in an oxidation state lower than VI seems to need temperatures higher than 200°C, even in the presence of highly dispersed metallic particles [35], the possibility of the formation of a molybdenum bronze, HxMoO3, should also be considered here [36]. Recently, similar behavior has been observed by Robinson et al. [37] and explained suggesting that there is a sufficient mixing of the two metals to prevent large domains that act as bulk Mo or Mo oxides. Mapping results of these samples seem to point in this direction. Although there are areas where both metals are in close contact, the presence of Mo and noble-metal particles without any kind of interaction is also observed and molybdenum species that are highly dispersed. The surface chemical composition of the fresh and spent catalysts was evaluated by XPS (Table 2 ). The Mo 3d core level spectra (Fig. 7 ) corresponding to bimetallic samples are quite noisy and not well defined making their decomposition difficult to perform in an accurate way. Instead, the Mo 3d spectrum corresponding to the Mo/Si sample is well defined and therefore the decomposition is shown in Fig. 7. Typically, it shows two Mo 3d 5/2 and Mo 3d 3/2 spin-orbit doublet contributions, respectively. Considering the position of the Mo 3d 5/2 components, two signals at ca. 232.1eV and 233.3eV are present, the main being the most important one and the binding energy typical of Mo(VI) species [38] and the higher binding energy could be associated to Mo(VI) species interacting in a stronger way. In the case of bimetallic samples, the Mo 3d spectra are quite noisy and therefore difficult to assign. Nonetheless, all of them are slightly shifted to lower values and this could be assumed to be due to some interaction with noble metal, as suggested from TPD results. Considering the Pd 3d spectra, two main peaks are observed corresponding to the 3d 5/2 and 3d 3/2 states from spin-orbit splitting; each of them can be decomposed into one or two contributions, depending on the oxidation states of the metal. It can be seen in Fig. 8 (left) that, in the case of the fresh sample, decomposition of the Pd 3d 5/2 signal leads to just one component centered at 336.6eV attributable to the PdO phase [39]. After testing, this contribution decreases and a new and more intense component appears at lower binding energy, 335.1eV, that can be associated to metallic Pd0, indicating that treatment of the catalyst during the catalytic test leads to partial reduction of the supported PdO. This remaining PdO may be due to incomplete reduction by the H2 contained in the reactor feed, although oxidation of metallic Pd particles by the water molecules formed during the catalytic reaction cannot be ruled out. With regard to Pt, the 4f 7/2 and 4f 5/2 spin-orbit doublet was used in the spectra analyses (Fig. 8 right). In the case of PtMo/Si fresh catalyst, the spectrum only shows one doublet, the 4f 7/2 component being centered at 71.1eV, which is assigned to Pt0 particles. After the test, a new and weaker doublet appears, whose 4f 7/2 component is centered at 72.5eV, which is characteristic of Pt(II) ions in the form of PtO [40]. Although, given the low-Pt loading in the PtMo/Si catalyst, the presence of Pt(II) species in the fresh catalyst cannot be ruled out. Undoubtedly, most of the Pt atoms must be in a zero-valent state. Thus, this new oxide phase in the spent catalyst must have appeared as a consequence of partial oxidation of the metallic phase by the water generated as a byproduct during the HDO reaction. Considering the surface atomic ratios, it is observed that the Pd(Pt)/Si atomic ratios are higher in the case of the Pd catalysts (fresh and spent), in accordance with better metallic dispersion of these catalysts as observed by XRD and TEM techniques. Moreover, after testing, no significant changes were observed for both the PdMo/Si and PtMo/Si catalysts, suggesting a good stability of the active phases during the catalytic test. 3.2 Catalytic study Catalysts with and without molybdenum were evaluated in the HDO reaction of DBF as a model molecule. First, the samples were tested at two different reaction temperatures: 250°C and 275°C and 30bar of pressure. The evolution of conversion was evaluated as a function of reaction time and the data represented in Fig. 9 . Several important differences were observed between both systems. The PdMo/Si catalyst showed a total conversion of 100% at both reaction temperatures evaluated; nevertheless, HDO conversion increased with temperature, from levels around 60% to almost 100%. In contrast, the PtMo/Si catalyst showed almost the same hydrogenation and deoxygenation conversions, which decreased slowly with time on stream at both temperatures evaluated. As with the Pd-based catalyst, those values increased when the temperature rose from 250 to 275°C. The HDO conversion is not substantially different for both catalysts when compared to the lowest temperature, 250°C, the greater difference being the higher hydrogenation ability of the PdMo/Si catalyst. Instead, PtMo/SiO2 presents a higher hydrogenolysis activity, being much more selective to O-free compounds. The effect of the reaction pressure on the conversion reveals that the noble metal plays an important role (Fig. 10 ). Thus, the PdMo/SiO2 catalyst suffered a decrease in the HDO capability when the pressure drops from 30 to 15bar. PtMo/SiO2 shows the same values of both total and HDO conversions when the reaction pressure is changed. Furthermore, the total and HDO conversion values in this latter catalyst stabilize within 6h on stream at a very high level of 80%. In summary, when temperature and pressure effects are taken into account, the general trend observed is that under less severe reaction conditions such as lower temperature and pressure values, the PtMo/SiO2 catalyst is always more effective in a way that all hydrogen consumed leads to O-free hydrogenated products. Monometallic catalysts were also evaluated in the HDO reaction of DBF, at 275°C and at 15bar of pressure. These catalysts fail to achieve the conversion values obtained with the bimetallic catalysts, the best conversion being that of the monometallic Pt catalyst, which, at 30bar, showed a HDO conversion value of 55%. Monometallic molybdenum oxide catalyst did not show activity under the same conditions. Fig. 11 compares the total and HDO activity of monometallic and bimetallic catalysts after 6h on stream. Important conclusions can be extracted from this graph. Although molybdenum oxide alone did not present catalytic activity, it plays an important role when added to a noble metal catalyst. Thus, in both bimetallic catalysts, the HDO capability improved compared to the monometallic ones. Therefore, it is thought that Mo promotes the hydrogenolysis reaction. Regarding the product distributions (selectivity values) obtained, they vary with conversion level, that is to say, they are a function of the catalytic activity. The main reaction products detected were: bicyclohexyl (BCH), cyclohexylbenzene (CHB), dodecahydrodibenzofuran (DHDBF), tetrahydrodibenzofuran (THDBF), hexahydrodibenzofuran (HHDBF), 2-cyclohexylphenol (2-CHP), bicyclohexyl-2-en-3-ol (BCH-2-en-3-ol), and cyclopentylmethylcyclohexane (C-PE-ME-CH). Table 3 shows data collected for all the supported catalysts after 6h on stream at both reaction temperatures and 30bar of pressure. As stated before, the main products obtained were BCH, CHB, and CH, as deoxygenated compounds, and DHDBF, HHDBF, THDBF, isomers BCH-3-en-2-ol, and 2-CHP, as intermediate oxygenates. In all cases the main product was BCH and a great proportion of O-intermediates are present at 250°C. BCH selectivities for PdMo/Si were 41% and 87% at 250°C and 275°C, respectively. In the case of PtMo/Si, these values were 36% and 75%, respectively. These data point to the hydrogenation route as the preferred one where ring saturation occurs. Taken together, the presented data indicates that hydrogenation is affected by the reaction temperature for the PdMo/Si catalyst, since the total conversion is close to 100% at both reaction temperatures, but O-removal is different. Thus at 250°C, the presence of an intermediate DHDBF is observed that is not detected at another temperature. If the effect of reaction pressure is considered (Table 4 ), the saturation of the aromatic rings leading to BCH is much greater at 30bar for Pd catalysts, that is, the hydrogenation ability depends on the hydrogen pressure employed when Pd is present. During the course of reaction, the selectivity to BCH was maintained constant at 30bar (not shown here), but at 15bar, it decreased from 80% to 50%. The decrease in selectivity of BCH was accompanied by a sharp increase of the oxygen intermediates. This suggests that the loss of activity suffered by this catalyst in the course of the reaction at 15bar, is due to some blockage of sites where CO rupture takes place. Instead, the selectivity pattern observed for the PtMo/Si catalyst (Table 4) is similar at both reaction pressures. A greater amount of CHB at expenses of BCH is observed at 15bar. Analyzing the active phase, it was observed that it had influence on the activity of the catalysts. Thus, the PtMo catalyst did not suffer deactivation along the catalytic reaction of HDO, while the catalyst based on PdMo presented a decrease in its activity. Furthermore, it was found that, while PtMo had no significant changes of activity with variations in pressure, PdMo presented greater conversion values at higher hydrogen pressures. Monometallic catalysts tested at 275°C and 15bar showed different behavior from the products obtained. They had worse performance than the bimetallic ones. Thus, the monometallic Pd/Si obtained BCH-3-en-2-ol as the main product; meanwhile Pt/Si presented a higher selectivity toward CPECH. Therefore, the addition of molybdenum to the active phase results in higher catalytic activity in the HDO reaction, obtaining higher yields of deoxygenated products, contrary to what occurs with monometallic catalysts. It improves the hydrogenolysis activity of the noble metal based catalyst. If literature data is considered, molybdenum has shown interesting results in HDO reactions presenting activity in the bulk state [23,38,41] and, depending on the support employed [24,42,43], for supported catalysts. Its activity is related to its capability to break CO bonds. It is reported that the activity of Mo relies on the presence of intermediate oxidation species (Mo5+ and Mo3+) [24]. Even some authors have suggested the presence of oxycarbide- and oxycarbohydride-containing phases (i.e., MoOxCyHz) [38]. Considering bimetallic samples, not much work is found in the literature about bimetallic systems noble metal-Mo. Recently, Yohe et al. [44] prepared a PtMo bimetallic sample containing a much higher metallic loading and studied it in the HDO reaction of several lignin derived bio-oils. These authors observed an improvement in the dehydration activity in the presence of Mo. Moreover, these authors reported the presence of metallic Mo alloyed with Pt, a molybdenum carbide-like phase (Mo carbide (MoxC) or oxy-carbide), and Mo oxide (MoOx). Robinson et al. [37] also observed an improvement in the deoxygenation behavior of a Pt catalyst by adding Mo in the HDO reaction of m-cresol. These authors, by using PtMo/Al2O3 systems (5wt%) explained by DFT studies that the barrier for m-cresol tautomerization and subsequent deoxygenation was lower in the presence of Mo and reported the presence of two types of Mo on the Al2O3 surface: Mo-Pt in close enough contact to have a synergistic effect and MoO3 clusters. In our case, TPD, TPR and XPS data agree with this point and not only in the case of Pt, but also in the case of Pd. TPD data of bimetallic samples give evidence that no desorption peak is observed at high temperature as observed in the case of monometallic Mo; in line with this, no reduction profile corresponding to Mo-reduction is present in the case of bimetallic samples. From the XPS results, in spite of quite noisy signals, the maximum is not centered at 228eV, the value reported for metallic molybdenum or Pt-Mo alloys [45]. Neither in the case of the Pd-containing one, the maximum is centered at those values. Moreover, the XRD data has also evidenced that by mixing noble metal-molybdenum the resultant dispersion is different to that observed in the case of the monometallic ones. The fact that Mo-diffraction peaks disappear in the bimetallic samples supports the idea that mixing Mo-noble metal prevents the formation of large domains that act as bulk Mo or Mo-oxides. Therefore, regardless of the noble metal employed, the reducibility, acidity, and dispersion of Mo-species change and this is possibly associated with the noble metal and Mo being close enough to exert a synergistic effect. This fact is also evidenced from mapping results. Besides, the addition of Mo provokes the same improvement in terms of catalytic response, an improvement in the hydrogenolysis activity of the resultant sample, regardless of the noble metal employed. 4 Conclusions Bi-functional catalysts based on Pt/Mo and Pd/Mo supported on silica have been prepared presenting good activity in the HDO reaction with high values of conversion and selectivity to deoxygenated products. Characterization results have shown that the dispersion of both components of the active phase varied compared to the monometallic samples, and thus noble metal dispersion decreases and molybdenum dispersion increases compared with the monometallic counterparts. Moreover, the acidity and reducibility of the resultant material is also affected when both phases are present. This plays an important role in the catalytic behavior of the resultant material, improving in both cases the hydrogenolysis capability of the bimetallic sample, being in all cases much higher than that of the monometallic counterpart. Moreover, the noble metal used also exerts an important role. The Pd-based sample presents better hydrogenation activity and the Pt-containing sample is always more effective in hydrogenolysis reactions, i.e., all hydrogen consumed leads to O-free hydrogenated products. coredata.dc:description: Molybdenum was incorporated into catalysts based on noble metals (Pt or Pd) and supported on silica in order to evaluate how its presence can modify the catalytic response of monometallic catalysts for hydrodeoxygenation (HDO). To this end, the catalysts were evaluated in the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) reaction of dibenzofuran (DBF) and characterized by different experimental techniques to understand its structure, texture and acidic properties. Catalytic results showed that the active phase had much influence on the activity and selectivity to different reaction products, although, in all cases, bicyclohexane (BCH) was the main reaction product observed. Molybdenum played a very important role in the case of bimetallic catalysts, mainly in the case of palladium. Molybdenum species improved the selectivity to O-free products related to its capacity to break the CO bond. However, molybdenum activity was nil in the absence of noble metal. Moreover, regardless of the noble metal employed, the reducibility, acidity and dispersion of the molybdenum species changed and this is possibly associated to a synergism effect between noble metal and Mo.
coredata.dc:title: Incorporation of molybdenum into Pd and Pt catalysts supported on commercial silica for hydrodeoxygenation reaction of dibenzofuran
